Certain as it is that Tacitus rejected Christianity, whether more or less deliberately‚ the question has some interest whether his adherence to the historical religion and ceremonial of Rome was hearty or indifferent. That it should be hearty is not as impossible as is generally imagined. Cicero’s famous saying about the two augum, coupled with the fact that he was an augur himself, makes us think that the whole of Roman paganism waS‚ so far as it affected educated people‚ a system of organised hypocrisy, kept up for the restraint of the vulgar.
